The Course on Positive Philosophy and the Friendship with Mill
4. The Course on Positive Philosophy and the Friendship with Mill

As said in its first lesson, the Course pursues two goals.
The first, a specific one, is a foundation for sociology, then called
‘social physics’. The second, a general goal, is the
coordination of the whole of positive knowledge. The structure of the
work reflects this duality: the first three volumes examine the five
fundamental sciences then in existence (mathematics, astronomy,
physics, chemistry, biology), and the final three volumes deal with
the social sciences. Executing the two parts did not require the same
amount of work. In the first case, the sciences had already been
formed and it was just a matter of summarizing their main doctrinal
and methodological points. In the other case, however, all was still
to be done, and Comte was well aware that he was founding a new
science.
